{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3378009,"name":"Steven Pearson","username":"spearson23","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/779978/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-01T16:02:25.456Z","cooked":"

We are looking to improve our prototyping for next year. Does anyone have any good suggestions on how to prototype quickly?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-05-01T16:02:25.456Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":50,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":345.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":465058,"topic_slug":"methods-of-prototyping","display_username":"Steven Pearson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":59244,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Steve (Mentor 555)"},"post_url":"/t/methods-of-prototyping/465058/1","custom_user_title":"Steve (Mentor 555)","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3378040,"name":"Everett33","username":"Everett33","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/everett33/{size}/5027_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-01T16:26:00.174Z","cooked":"
  • 1/4" Plywood
  • 2x4s
  • PVC Pipe
  • 1.125" hole saw
  • A way to hook a cordless drill to a 1/2" Hex shaft
  • Electrical tape for quick hex shaft spacers
  • An assortment of squish and other wheels
  • Brushed motors like cims, mini cims, bag motors so you dont need to program anything

There are a lot of existing threads on tools, techniques, and ecosystems team have developed with 3D printed parts to make prototype assembly and testign faster.

OTB Intake Prototyping System CAD
[Proto System Assembly(3)] Onshape Document After recently coming into possession of a laser cutter, I thought id make a system for prototyping intakes to test it out. I wanted to be able to easily change between bumper heights. Currently its only a matter of swapping the single 3D printed standoff block to change the height of the bumper, no need to mess with bolt lengths or multiple spacers. The Onshape document is setup to generate these spacers for arbitrary bumper heights between 1/4" …
Protopipe - Spectrum 3847 Technical Discussion
https://imgur.com/YAiW4S2.png We have been working on creating a system to allow us to quickly and easily design mechanisms that let us prototype game tasks. What we have come up with is called “Protopipe”. It’s an inexpensive system that lets you 3D print connectors for 1/2" PVC to easily build prototypes, test them, and iterate them. We haven’t run it through a season yet so there is almost certainly room for improvement but we thought other teams might like to use it as well. Blog Post: ht…
How do you effectively prototype? CAD
A good complement to LAD is CAD (Cardboard Aided Design). We used it to prototype several iterations of the passive Gear mechanism in 2017 in a couple of hours. We used the last version as patterns to cut the polycarb for the final version.
How to make rough prototypes quickly? General Forum
This Early prototypes for intakes or game piece acquisition mechanisms can be stand-alone, but acquiring from a moving robot is a critical part of prototyping. Having a drive base ready to run and mount things to is incredibly useful.
Suggestions for Prototyping Equipment General Forum
One thing we did way back in the day when 5030 was still hand tools for everything but we still had cass of all our robots. make it easier to catch mistakes or known packaging limitations. print out to scale designs that kids can use as a “cookie cutter”, for where they need to cut or drill. still help with easier reiteration, 3D printing or figuring how to adjust/build in our limits. We had spent 2014-2016 building all by hand and didn’t get access to a Cnc until 2017 and even still we had m…

Head Coach"},"post_url":"/t/methods-of-prototyping/465058/2","custom_user_title":"5660 - Head Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3378060,"name":"Ian","username":"TrackpadCAD","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/f0a364/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-01T16:41:14.218Z","cooked":"

I like to logically split prototyping into two groups: archetype prototyping and variable prototyping. Archetype prototyping for this year looked something like “Should we do horizontal or vertical flywheel sets?”, variable prototyping this year was “how much compression should the shooter have on the note?”.

The biggest thing to remember when prototyping is you’re not trying to optimize it, you want it do quick and dirty and good enough to answer your question. Our early prototypes were jigsawed 3/4" plywood with random lengths of 0.5" hex shaft we had around and electrical tape spacers driven by drills with a 1/2" socket. Once we decided on our archetype, we then got a little more fancy as we honed in on our solution, CNCd plywood and whatnot.

The attached picture is one of our later prototypes

image638×552 65.8 KB

We use a 1/2 hex socket

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T15:52:44.684Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":66,"readers_count":65,"score":43.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":465058,"topic_slug":"methods-of-prototyping","display_username":"Harrison","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":69483,"username":"Rubicon","name":"Eric Binu","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rubicon/{size}/245732_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57833,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/methods-of-prototyping/465058/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3547270,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T16:42:12.744Z","cooked":"

Also, while regular hex shaft doesn’t usually fit into a 1/2" cordless drill chuck, rounded hex (e.g., REV Rounded Hex) sometimes does.

This is very useful for answering certain questions, such as, “which wheel is grippiest?”. Instead of putting together a whole rig, you can stick a single wheel on the shaft and retain it with a shaft collar. Unlike a 1/2" socket, it won’t drop out of the drill, and you don’t need to have something else pushing on the far side to retain the shaft.

If you have something with a longer overhang, it’s better to build a frame, install bearings, and use the socket.
